scenarios.context: You are a settled down migrant woman currently going throughout your day in the city of Melbourne. Today, you take the train on your daily commute to work, you just hang up talking to one of your friends on the phone, when the passenger next to you starts rudely mocking your accent and laughing making you very uncomfortable.
scenarios.question: What should you do?

responses.text: Don’t give them a response and move away from them as far as you can
responses.feedback: Whilst this is a good way to respond to harassment, moving away from the harasser may lead to them chasing you down out of anger from being ignored.

responses.text: Tell them to stop as their comments are deeply hurtful and you are not okay with it
responses.feedback: It’s good to be assertive in most situations; however, directly engaging with the harasser would most likely lead to even more confrontation, which is best to be avoided.

responses.text: Inform the nearest public transport staff as soon as you can so that they can record it for police use
responses.feedback: Reporting to a member of staff will ensure that this incident is formally documented so that it can be actioned properly by the local authorities.

scenarios.context: You are doing your weekly shopping in a supermarket, you seem lost on where to find a certain item and ask a member of staff where you can find it. They take one look at you and make an extremely backhanded remark at your ethnicity before telling you where the item is.
scenarios.question: How should you respond?

responses.text: Respond in a very angry manner so that everyone in the store can hear you
responses.feedback: Confronting the issue in such a brash manner would only escalate the situation against your favor, as now you have negative attention turned towards you, which could easily be swayed to be your fault.

responses.text: Ask to see their manager so that you can report their behaviour
responses.feedback: There are policies and procedures in place at shopping centres against this kind of behavior, so reporting it to the manager is the easiest way of having them dealt with properly.

responses.text: Ignore their response and thank them for pointing you in the right direction
responses.feedback: Don’t brush off a racist comment without fighting back as it’s morally incorrect and should never be happening to you.

scenarios.context: You are going for a walk outside on public roads and always pass by a group of locals on your walk. Every time you walk by these people, they always unjustly remark on how you dress, look, and act.
scenarios.question: What should you do in this situation?

responses.text: Change your walk route to avoid this group of people
responses.feedback: Melbourne is a city where you shouldn’t give up so easily to harassers. There are laws to protect you, and you should use them.

responses.text: Have a strong verbal argument with them so they stop harassing you
responses.feedback: Picking an argument by yourself with a harasser can already be risky, but doing it to a group of harassers is far too dangerous. You shouldn’t face them alone; get help from the proper authorities.

responses.text: Report this group to the local authorities and give them the group’s location
responses.feedback: By reporting them, you give the police a case that they can investigate, and if the group doesn’t move, they can be dealt with swiftly.

scenarios.context: You are the mother of a child and drop them off for their first day of school. However, when they come back, they start crying saying that they were made fun of and bullied because they looked different from everyone else.
scenarios.question: What should you do?

responses.text: Inform the police about what transpired so they can handle the situation
responses.feedback: That is incorrect. Whilst getting the police involved can get the problem sorted, they aren’t equipped to handle these types of cases with the proper knowledge on discrimination laws.

responses.text: Contact the school’s principal and express your concerns about the racism your child is facing
responses.feedback: That is correct. Schools all have anti-racism policies in place, and you should make use of these as they can properly protect your child from discrimination within the school ecosystem.

responses.text: Tell the child to just ignore the bullies and focus on making friends instead
responses.feedback: That is incorrect. Children should never have to feel scared and sad coming home from school. All children deserve to have a safe and welcoming space to have a quality education, and you shouldn’t forsake that right.

scenarios.context: You are out eating lunch with your childhood friend Fatima at a restaurant. She gets a call on her phone and steps outside to take it. She starts taking too much time, so you look through the window to see what’s happening and see she’s having an argument with an intoxicated person who claims that she 'doesn’t belong here.' You can see the situation escalating, with the intoxicated person getting more and more violent and Fatima becoming less and less safe.
scenarios.question: What emergency number should you call to stop this?

responses.feedback: The Australia Emergency Services number is 000.
